I adore Episode 2. Every moment of this game is the peak of Half-Life 2; weapons, vehicles, and unique gameplay sections are ratcheted up a lot, and it lends to an awesome but short experience.

White Forest Inn is one of my favorite locations in gaming as a whole. I'm not sure why, but it's such a quaint location with a very fun sequence attached.

Really liked the expansion on advisors, and the callback to using a rocket in Half-Life 1 feels good.

Stop reading reviews and go play it.

That... is a 10/10.

This game came out back in 2007. Yet still, Half-Life as a series really is something. The story is actually rich, and it felt at least to me, even more fleshed out in episode two. The dialogue is getting better to the point where interactions are feeling more human. The graphics are getting better don't get me wrong, but for a 2007 game it still manages to set scenes and create atmospheres that give you a bit of an emotional roller coaster throughout. 

Playing this now in 2022 I can say easily this is better than a lot of modern triple A games and I loved every minute of it. Although Alyx do be gettin' kinda thirsty the more the game goes on, which is pretty impressive for a guy who hasn't said a word from start to finish. Freeman you stud. But, even though her dialogue is crisp and very fitting for how her character has developed, I'd take a Vorti companion anyday. They;re infinitely more useful, deadly and are great shoulders to cry on.

I can now join the church of Half-Lifers praying to Gaben every day for Half-Life 3. There must be a reason our saviour has left us on such a cliff hanger, surely this delay isn't just punishment for our sins.

This game is one which I have waited all my life to play. I have known of its significance on the gaming industry, the impact of its cliffhanger and meaningful connection to story and characters, yet I did not know exactly what I was in store for. I have been steamrolling (lol steam pun) my way through the entire series blindly from Black Mesa to Half-Life 2, episode 1 and now here. Gordon's journey has touched me emotionally in ways I have not felt from a game in a long time. I felt, as he rightfully felt, the desparation and futility surrounding him yet none of which held him back from stepping up to do as he had to for his friends and the fate of humanity. 

When compared to Episode 1, I think I did enjoy the experience of this one a bit more. Episode 1 felt shorter somehow, while this story felt more whole. I loved Arne Magnusson, he was so hilarious and the humor was not at all unfitting alongside the other characters. His interactions with Gordon, Alyx, Eli and Kleiner were fabulous and I wish to get to know him more. My biggest complaint was not knowing the fate of Barney Calhoun since episode 1. He did not make it to White Forest ahead of me as I thought he might, and as he is one of my favorites I do worry for him. Speaking of worry, I sincerely hope Lamarr is not lost for good. 

By this point in the story, so many games deep, there's no way my emotional connection to Dr. Freeman could be severed, nothing to make the pain of not knowing what happens next go away. I am now among the thousands of others lying in wait for our lord & savior, Gaben, to deliver us the finale that was promised and is needed more than ever. Half-Life Alyx gives me hope that Valve haven't given up on games or this franchise just yet. I'll be saving up for a Steam Index now to experience it for myself, because this whole series means so much to me that I'll do anything to be in this world again. 

Please Gaben, honor your promises of years passed for Episode 3, or Half-Life 3 entirely if that is the case now. 

Yours woefully in waiting, 

-Hannah
